pythonta.technical.find_peaks(dataframe, clearance=5, method=0, what=0)¶

Calculates peaks for the given dataframe.

Parameters

  • dataframe (pandas) – Dataframe containing the price data.

  • clearance (int) – Nr of candles to clear on both sides of the peak

  • method – User CLASSIC or MODERN style for peak detection

  • what (const) – Selects whether TOPS or BOTTOMS will be returned.

Returns

indexes

Return type

array

Note

The dataframe must contain the columns ‘High’ and ‘Low’.

Note

CLASSIC peak stick out on a horizontal level. MODERN peaks also consider the trend of surrounding candles.

pythonta.technical.find_regression_line(dataframe)¶

Returns a regression line for the given dataframe.

Parameters

dataframe (pandas) – Dataframe containing the price data.

Returns

line

Return type

(x1, y1, x2, y2)

pythonta.technical.find_support_and_ressitance(dataframe, clearance=5, what=0)¶

Calculates support or resistance levels for the given dataframe.

Parameters

  • dataframe (pandas) – Dataframe containing the price data.

  • clearance (int) – Nr of candles to clear on both sides of the peak

  • what (const) – Selects whether SUPPORTS or RESISTS will be returned.

Returns

lines

Return type

array

Note

The dataframe must contain the columns ‘High’ and ‘Low’.

Note

The returned array of lines are in the format (x1,y1,x2,y2) where x1 and x2 are indexes into the dataframe and Y1 and Y2 are actual price points.

pythonta.technical.find_trendlines(dataframe, clearance=5, what=0)¶

Calculates trendlines for the given dataframe.

Parameters

  • dataframe (pandas) – Dataframe containing the price data.

  • clearance (int) – Nr of candles to clear on both sides of the peak

  • what (const) – Selects whether SUPPORTS or RESISTS will be returned.

Returns

lines

Return type

array

Note

The dataframe must contain the columns ‘High’ and ‘Low’.

Note

The returned array of lines are in the format (x1,y1,x2,y2) where x1 and x2 are indexes into the dataframe and Y1 and Y2 are actual price points.

pythonta.utils.translate(value, fromBegin, fromEnd, toBegin, toEnd)¶
Translates a point from one system to the other. A system is defined (but

not limited) by a begin- and end-value.

Parameters:

value : The point to be transformed fromBegin, fromEnd : System in which the value parameter is now toBegin, toEnd : System to which value is to be translated

Returns:

translated value in the new system

Notes: 1. For examele; if you wanted 10 on a scale of 1-10 to be translated to a

scale of 20-40 you would do:

v_new = translate(10, 1, 10, 20, 40)
